Table 1 presents comparative results between different methods. The results show that our MMQ significantly outperforms other meta-learning methods by a large margin. Besides, the gain in performance of MMQ is stable with different attention mechanisms (BAN [15] or SAN [43]) in the VQA task.
It worth noting that, compared with the most recent state-of-the-art method MEVF [26], we outperform 5.3%percent5.35.3\% in free-form questions of the PathVQA dataset and 9.8%percent9.89.8\% in the Open-ended questions of the VQA-RAD dataset, respectively.
Moreover, no out-of-dataset images are used in MMQ for learning meta-models.
The results imply that our proposed MMQ learns essential representative information from the input images and leverage effectively the features from meta-models to deal with challenging questions in medical VQA datasets.

Table 2 presents our MMQ accuracy in PathVQA dataset when applying m𝑚m times refining data and n𝑛n quantified meta-models. The results show that, by using only 111 quantified meta-model outputted from our MMQ, we significantly outperform both MAML and MEVF baselines.
This confirms the effectiveness of the proposed MMQ for dealing with the limitation of meta-annotation in medical VQA, i.e., noisy labels and scalability. Besides, leveraging more quantified meta-models also further improves the overall performance.

Table 2 also shows that increasing the number of refinement steps and the number of quantified meta-models can improve the overall result, but the gain is smaller after each loop. The training time also increases when the number of meta-models is set higher. However, our testing time and the total number of parameters are only slightly higher than MAML [6] and MEVF [26]. Based on the empirical results, we recommend applying 555 times refinement with a maximum of 333 quantified meta-models to balance the trade-off between the accuracy performance and the computational cost.

references: Table 3 illustrates the performance of MMQ with different amounts of meta-annotated images for training meta models. Since our data refinement module (See Algorithm 1 in our paper) expands current meta-data as well as removes uncertainty samples simultaneously, keeping the balance in the number of samples between meta-data and unlabeled data at the initial step is worthy. Empirical results also imply that the initial data balance between two data pools greatly increases the effectiveness of our proposed MMQ.
